t: He that hateth reproof shall take the path of the sinner, but he that feareth the Lord shall turn again in his heart.
The fair speaker is known everywhere, but the man of understanding knoweth his failings.
To build one's house with the money of others is to gather stones for one's tomb.
The congregation of sinners is a heap of tow, and the end thereof is a flame of fire.
The way of sinners is made smooth with stones, but at the end thereof is the pit of Sheol.
He that keepeth the law hath mastery over his inclination, and the perfection of the fear of the Lord is wisdom.
He that is without natural gifts cannot learn, but there are gifts that bring forth bitterness.
The knowledge of the wise aboundeth like a flood, and his counsel is like a fountain of life.
The heart of the fool is like a broken vessel that holdeth no knowledge.
If a man of understanding heareth a wise word, he approveth it, and addeth thereto; but if a libertine heareth it, it displeaseth him, and he casteth it behind him.
The discourse of the fool is like a burden on a journey, but on the lips of the wise is found grace.
The word of the man of understanding is sought after in the congregation, and whatsoever he saith, every man pondereth it in his heart.
A house in ruins, such is the wisdom of the fool, and the knowledge of the senseless is incoherent speech.
Discipline for the senseless is as fetters on his feet, and as manacles on his right hand.
A fool raiseth his voice when he laugheth, but a man of sense laugheth rarely and discreetly.
For a man of sense discipline is a jewel of gold, a bracelet on his right arm.
A fool hasteneth to enter in, but a man of experience taketh a modest stance;
Through the door the senseless looketh within, but the well-bred man remaineth without.
It is the deed of one poorly brought up to listen at doors, but a man of sense feeleth the dishonor thereof.
The lips of the gossiper chatter of that which concerneth him not, but the words of the wise are carefully weighed.
The heart of fools is in their mouth, but the mouth of the wise is in their heart.
When the impious curseth Satan, he curseth his own soul.
The backbiter doeth hurt to his own self, and is hated of them that are about him.
The sluggard is like unto a stone covered with filth, and every man doth hiss at him for his ignominy.
The sluggard is like unto a handful of dung, and whosoever toucheth him shaketh his hand.
It is a shame for a father to have begotten a son poorly brought up, and if it be a daughter, it causeth loss.
A wise daughter shall find a husband, but a daughter of no worth is the grief of him that begat her.
A shameless daughter dishonoreth her father and her husband, and both of them reject her.
Untimely remonstrances are as music in a day of mourning, but stripes and correction are wisdom at all times.
Children who lead a life of honesty, lacking in nothing, cause men to forget the obscure origin of their parents.
Children that are scornful, ill-bred, and full of pride defile the nobility of their family.
It is like gluing potsherds together to teach a fool, and like waking a man heavy with sleep.
To reason with a fool is to reason with a slumbering man, and in the end he will say: "What is it about?

Weep for the dead, for he hath lost the light, and weep for the fool, for he hath lost his understanding; weep more gently for the dead, for he hath found rest, but for the fool life is sadder than death.
For the dead mourning lasteth seven days, but for the fool and the ungodly all the days of their life.

Address not much discourse to a fool, and go not to speak with the senseless, for he will be insensible and will cover thee with scorn, keep thee from him lest thou have vexation, and be not sullied by his contact. Turn away from him, and thou shalt find rest, and thou shalt not be wearied by his wanderings.
What is heavier than lead? And what is its name? The fool.
Sand, salt, and a mass of iron are easier to bear than the fool.

A framework of timber joined together in a building doth not suffer itself to be disjointed by an earthquake; a heart resolved, after mature deliberation, doth not suffer itself to be moved in the hour of danger.
A heart supported by wise reflection is like an ornament carved upon a polished wall.
Small stones on the top of a wall do not withstand the wind: the heart of the fool, frightened by his imaginations, cannot withstand fear.
By striking the eye, tears flow, and by striking the heart feelings appear.
He that throweth a stone at birds chaseth them away, and he that reproacheth his friend breaketh friendship.
If thou hast drawn the sword against thy friend, despair not, for he may return;

If thou hast opened thy mouth against thy friend, fear not, for reconciliation is possible, save in the case of outrage, scorn, betrayal of a secret, and a treacherous blow, for then every friend will depart.

Gain the confidence of thy neighbor in his poverty, that in his prosperity thou mayest rejoice with him in his goods; in the days of trial be faithful to him, that thou mayest receive, if he come to inherit, thy share of the inheritance. For one must never despise the contours, nor admire a rich man devoid of sense.
Preceding the flames is seen the vapor of the burning brand, and smoke; so preceding bloodshed are insults.
I shall not be ashamed to protect a friend, and from him will I not hide myself;
And if any evil befall me by him, all that hear thereof shall beware of him.
Who will set a watch over my mouth, and upon my lips the seal of discernment, that I may not stumble thereby, and that my tongue may not cause my destruction?
O Lord, father and master of my life, leave me not to stumble thereby.
Who will apply the scourge to my thoughts, and to my heart the discipline of wisdom, that my errors may not be spared, and that my sins may not escape?
Lest my errors be multiplied, and my sins abound, and I fall into the hands of my adversaries, and mine enemy mock me. Far from them is the hope of thy mercy.
O Lord, father, and God of my life, abandon me not to their caprice; grant that my looks may not be brazen,
Turn away from me covetousness,
Let not the appetite of the flesh, nor lust, take hold of me, and deliver me not up to impudent desire.
Hearken, my children, to an instruction concerning the mouth, and he that keepeth it shall not be confounded.
The sinner is taken by his own lips, and they bring low the backbiter and the proud.
Accustom not thy mouth to swearing, neither use thyself to the naming of the Holy One.
For as a servant that is continually watched will not escape a blow, so he that sweareth and nameth the Name wrongfully shall not be free from sin.

A man prodigal of oaths is full of impiety, and the scourge shall not depart from his house. If he sin, his fault shall be upon him; if he act lightly, he hath sinned doubly; if he make a false oath, he shall not be justified, for his house shall be full of calamities.
There is a way of speaking that resembleth death; let it not be in use in the inheritance of Jacob, for godly men turn away from all such things, and wallow not in sin.
Accustom not thy mouth to gross impurity wherein is the word of sin.

Remember thy father and thy mother when thou sittest in the midst of great men, lest thou forget thyself in their presence, and behave as a fool, and come to wish that thou hadst not been born, and curse the day of thy birth.
A man accustomed to reproachful words will not be corrected all his life.

Two sorts of beings multiply sins, and the third bringeth wrath: passion burning like a firebrand; it will not be quenched until it be satisfied; the man that lusteth after his own flesh; he will not cease until the fire consume him;
To the shameless man all food is sweet; he will not calm down until he die.
The man unfaithful to his own bed who saith in his heart: "Who seeth me? Darkness surroundeth me, the walls protect me, no one seeth me, what should I fear? The Most High will not remember my faults.

What he feareth is the eyes of men, but he knoweth not that the eyes of the Lord are ten thousand times brighter than the sun, that they observe all the actions of men, and penetrate into the most secret recesses.
Before he created, all things were known unto him, and so they are also after they are finished.
In the midst of the city this man shall be punished, and when he least expecteth it he shall be taken.
The same is true of the woman unfaithful to her husband, who bringeth him an heir conceived of a stranger.
First of all she hath disobeyed the law of the Most High, then she is guilty against her husband; thirdly she hath defiled herself by adultery, and hath conceived children of a stranger.
She shall be brought before the assembly, and her children shall be examined.
Her children shall have no roots, and her branches shall bear no fruit.
She shall leave a memory of cursing, and her shame shall never be blotted out.
And they that come after her shall know that nothing is so good as the fear of the Lord, and that nothing is sweeter than to cleave unto the commandments of the Lord.
To follow God is a great honor; it is to prolong thy days to be received by him.
Wisdom shall praise herself, and shall glory in the midst of her people.
In the assembly of the Most High she shall open her mouth, and before his Power she shall glory.
"I came forth from the mouth of the Most High, and covered the earth like a mist.
"I dwelt in high places, and my throne is in a cloudy pillar.
"I alone have compassed the circuit of heaven, and have walked in the bottom of the deep.
"In the waves of the sea, and in all the earth, and in every people and nation, I got a possession.
"With all these I sought rest: and in whose inheritance shall I abide?
"Then the Creator of all things gave me a commandment; and he that made me caused my tabernacle to rest, and said, Let thy dwelling be in Jacob, and thine inheritance in Israel.
"From the beginning, before the world, was I created, and unto the world to come I shall not cease to be.
"In the holy tabernacle I served before him; and so was I established in Sion.
"Likewise in the beloved city he gave me rest: and in Jerusalem was my power.
"And I took root in an honourable people, and in the portion of my God was mine inheritance.
"I was exalted like a cedar in Libanus, and as a cypress tree upon the mountains of Hermon.
"I was exalted like a palm tree in Engaddi, and as a rose plant in Jericho, as a fair olive tree in a pleasant field, and grew up as a plane tree by the water.

"As the cinnamon tree and aspalathus, I yielded a sweet savour; as a myrrh of choice I spread abroad a pleasant odour; as galbanum, and onyx, and sweet storax, and as the fume of frankincense in the tabernacle.
"As a turpentine tree I stretched out my branches, and my branches are the branches of honour and grace.
"I am the vine which bringeth forth a pleasant savour, and my flowers are the fruit of honour and riches.
"I am the mother of fair love, and fear, and knowledge, and holy hope: I therefore, being eternal, am given to all my children which are named of him.
"Come unto me, all ye that be desirous of me, and fill yourselves with my fruits.
"For my memorial is sweeter than honey, and mine inheritance than the honeycomb.
"They that eat me shall yet be hungry, and they that drink me shall yet be thirsty.
"He that obeyeth me shall never be confounded, and they that work by me shall not sin.
